SD / UHS-I Compliant SDHC / SDXC / Type I Compact Flash (UDMA Compliant)

This camera has brilliant features for the price it has to offer. The high ISO is phenomenal and gives way less noise at 6400 as well. I have tested this camera in extreme low light conditions and was satisfied with it.The 45degree curve towards its shutter gives you a good grip while shooting. Nikon did remove some buttons from its previous release the D700 but the new buttons are for the good only.

Simply a marvel from Nikon. Upgraded from D7000 and loving this awesome piece of engineering. Slight green tint on the LCD is indeed there when compared to other camera screens but not an issue as such.Pros: Resolution is great! Details are fantabulous! very good dynamic range! auto-Focus and Exposure are excellent! Great value for money.Still have to explore the video mode but initial impressions are good.Cons:Still have to find out except the marginal green tint.

I have upgraded from D90. Got this camera a few days back. There is definitely a greenish tint in the LCD, especially photos take with flash indoors. I have compared the same photograph in both D90 and D800 and the photo looks much better and natural on D90 screen. However it seems to be an LCD issue and not image issue as the tint in not there when viewed on computer screen. Other than that, things seem fine, although I havent used all the features yet. But remember that if you want to upgrade from an entry level or mid range DSLR, you will feel that the D800 is bigger and heavier and will feel weird carrying it for casual shots. If you pair it with a pro lens like 24-70 f/2.8, then it gets really heavy for casual use. So weigh your needs and decide accordingly.

This is my 6th DSLR body from Nikon and the best till date. Its not an everyday camera for hobbyists but the perfect main body for Pro users who are making an income through photography. If you are a hobbyist and not planning on any commercial ventures, but crazy about full frame sensors, look for D600 and D610, that will meet all your needs.I rate it as my best because: 1) D4 is too expensive and heavy for long hours of shooting like a wedding or event.2) D800 gives high details and high ISO performance.3) Same batteries as D600 which is my second body.4) Button layout is the best to wish for as I had a D700 before.Cons: A normal SDHC card may struggle if you are shooting in RAW. Best match would be something in the grade of Sandisk Extreme Pro. I use 16 GB cards. Its more practical to have many 16 GB cards than having one or two 32 GB cards.

Hi guys Nikon D 800 is out standing camera which can beat canon 5d mark iii .it as excellent sharpness color brightness and very good qualities i enjoy this cam by having candide photography in wedding it has very good low lite sensors ...and more on its has 36.2 megapix which can used for advertising H d quality pic s Or movies thank u NIKON i love it .
Best camera for non-wildlife photography - as good as a medium format

- Excellent make and results.- DO NOT COMPARE IT WITH SLRs : its not meant to be compared with SLRs as its more like a medium format killer than a SLR replacement or a video camera- DO NOT USE FOR VIDEOS - apart from killing the shutter life, the sensor line skipping gives low quality output compared even blackmagic.- PDR curves are the best way to compare with medium formatsBest Points:* Excellent Dynamic Range* ADL works like a charm* Excellent performance with old block lenses - 1.2f 50mm, 85mm 1.8f etc thus making it easy for portraits and low light caputre* Excellent results in low light life / street photographyPS: decided to write the review as I am very happy with the results and tired to answering questions regarding how it stands compared to another company's flagship. The camera has survived 1+ year of dust, sand, high humidity & rain & works well now. Also, the lenses are all high aperture pro lenses, so the results may vary. The results with old prime lenses are the best thing I have seen in sometime.
You get double of your Money

I am using this Little Beast for the last one-n-half year in almost all types of photography.36.3 Megapixel is a bliss, you get more detail in less money, if you don't want 36.3, there are options to reduce in smaller sizes.It is an all-metal & Japan manufactured body, D600&D610 both are china plastic.The Dynamic Range is something to be desired from an real advanced technology.It has a pop-up flash, not only for dark subjects, but you can command other speed-lights remotely with this.(Mark 2 or 3 can't do this)Some really crazy in-camera shooting menu introduced.Almost similar button locations for easier upgrade from D700.Great smooth ISO for low light (I saw almost similar in Mark 3 but you pay 1Lac more)There is nothing more to write, everything is excellent and awsome with this camera, I am really loving it.Only few things I wanted the company to look after in the next upgrade:Frame speed/Burst should be little better for a top choice camera like this, megapixels are no excuse, people pay for performance.Should have 2 SD slots, as nowadays SD cards are cheaper and versatile.LCD tilt option could help shooters in better thinking and showing.Better weather sealing. One rainy season, and my viewfinder got some hairline internal fungus, My fault, I should have carried silica in my bag while traveling in rain.This D800 coupled with a professional 24-70 f/2.8 lens costs similar to a MarK-3 body only.Giving 5 star because there are only 5.
